subject: AI
title: Managing User Expectations
description: Setting the right expectations so users aren't disappointed by AI limitations.

hook.text: Users see 'AI-powered' and expect perfection. When the AI makes a mistake, trust drops to zero. Not because the AI was bad, but because expectations were wrong.

buildup.text: Expectation management starts with how you frame the feature. 'AI-generated draft (please review)' sets different expectations than 'AI answer' or 'Smart recommendation.'

discovery.text: Use language that implies assistance, not authority: 'suggested,' 'draft,' 'may include errors,' 'based on available data.' Make it clear the AI is helping, not deciding.

twist.text: Under-promise, over-deliver. If you say 'this might not be perfect' and it IS perfect, users are delighted. If you imply perfection and it's 95% right, users focus on the 5% failure.

climax.text: The best AI products train users to expect AI-level quality (very good but not perfect) and make it easy to correct mistakes when they happen.

punchline.text: Frame AI as a helpful assistant, not an oracle. Users forgive assistants. They don't forgive liars.

quiz.question: How should AI features be framed to manage expectations?
options: As helpful suggestions that may need review
Without any indication that AI is involved
